metadata.case_name: State of Bihar v. Rai Bahadur Hurdut Roy Motilal Jute Mills

facts.text: Rai Bahadur Hurdut Roy Motilal Jute Mills (first respondent) was registered dealer under Bihar Sales Tax Act, 1947, carrying on business of manufacture and sale of gunny bags, Hessian and other jute products at Katihar.
During April 1, 1950 to March 31, 1951, first respondent sold and despatched wares worth Rs. 92,24,386 to dealers outside Bihar and realised Rs. 2,11,222-9-6 as sales tax from such dealers.
Assessment taken up by Superintendent of Sales Tax, Purnea (second respondent) on May 31, 1953.
Following Supreme Court decision in State of Bombay v. United Motors (India) Ltd. (1953 SCR 1069), turnover of Rs. 92,24,386 exempted from tax, deducted from total turnover.
Notice under s.14A issued to first respondent on June 18, 1954, to show cause why Rs. 2,11,222-9-6 should not be forfeited.
Order of forfeiture passed on February 10, 1955, directing deposit of amount into treasury.
First respondent applied to Patna High Court under Arts. 226 and 227 challenging order; High Court allowed petition on August 1, 1956, set aside order.
Similar facts in Civil Appeals Nos. 546 of 1958 and 115 of 1959; Patna High Court judgments dated March 8, 1957.
Section 33(1)(a)(i) of Act enacted April 4, 1951, retrospective from January 26, 1950; sales outside Bihar not taxable.
At material time, confusion about Art. 286; dealers paid and collected tax on inter-state transactions; notification levied tax at three pies on despatched goods.

legal_issues.text: Whether proviso to s.14A of Bihar Sales Tax Act, 1947 attracted to collections on inter-state sales exempt under s.33(1)(a)(i), due to contravention of proviso to r.19.
Whether proviso to s.14A violates Art.20(1) or Art.31(2) of Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: Proviso to r.19 contravened as turnover under s.33(1)(a)(i) allowed to be deducted from gross turnover; no justification to collect tax; breaches s.14A and r.19.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.14A, proviso to r.19, s.33(1)(a)(i), s.2(i)

petitioner_arguments.text: Proviso to s.14A does not violate Art.20(1) or Art.31(2).

respondent_arguments.text: Proviso to r.19 not attracted; exclusion under s.33(1)(a)(i) not 'allowable deduction' under explanation to s.5 or r.19; transactions outside Act.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.33(1)(a)(i), proviso to r.19, explanation to s.5, ss.6,7,8

respondent_arguments.text: Proviso to s.14A ultra vires violating Art.20(1) and Art.31(2).

court_reasoning.text: Transactions under s.33(1)(a)(i) outside Act; exclusion not 'allowable deduction' under proviso to r.19, which refers to deductions under ss.5 expl., 6,7,8.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Allowable deduction under proviso not same as exclusion under s.33; transactions in substance outside Act.

court_reasoning.text: No contravention of s.14A; collections outside s.14A but not contravention thereof; r.19 proviso imposes penalty only for specified breaches.
Form VI structured for deductions under ss.6,7,8, not s.33 exclusions; gross turnover may mean taxable turnover.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Straining language of r.19 proviso not warranted.

court_reasoning.text: No need to decide constitutional issues as proviso not attracted.

holdings.text: Proviso to s.14A not invoked; order of forfeiture unjustified and illegal.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. United Motors (India) Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.286(1)(a) with expl. prohibits taxation of inter-state sales except delivery state.

statutes_cited.name: Bihar Sales Tax Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Scheme of tax on sales in Bihar; s.14A allows collections subject to rules; proviso forfeits contravening collections; s.33 excludes inter-state sales.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal; constitutional challenges to proviso; Art.286 limits state taxing power on inter-state sales.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; orders of forfeiture set aside as proviso to s.14A not attracted; decision governs other appeals; no consideration of constitutional issues.

key_quotes.text: An allowable deduction under the said proviso was number the same thing as exclusion of a part of the turn-over on the basis of s. 33 1 a 1 of the Act. It stands on an entirely different footing.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core distinction rejecting application of r.19 proviso

key_quotes.text: Transactions which fall within the said section are in substance outside the Act and number tax can be imposed on them.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why s.33 exclusion not 'deduction' under rules

key_quotes.text: Courts are and should be reluctant to decide companystitutional points merely as matters of academic importance.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Reason for not addressing Art.20/31 issues
